171187651.review:
Simply one of the greatest CRPGs ever made, Witcher 3 is the game that made Geralt of Rivia famous. There's not much to say about this that hasn't already been said. It's perennially at or near the top of multiple reviewers' "best ever" lists (including mine). Only the gameplay doesn't quite hold up to modern standards; the actual combat is easy and the enemies predictable. Don't expect a soulslike here. It's not a chore to play, but the real draws are the characters and the story.

Highly recommended to any fan of role-playing games.

171150097.review:
This is the perfect way to close a trilogy, the Witcher 3 takes lessons learned from Witcher 1 and Witcher 2.
The result it's an amazing open world experience where the player is in control and exploration it's rewarded.
World exploration, rewards, side quest, hunts, choices, skill tree, investigations, many endings, political intrigue to name a few are a core aspect of this game.
You will play this game multiple times for multiple endings and for fun, go vanilla or mod it you decide.
Awesome experience, great writing, great game, tons of fun it's pure SLAV MAGIC.

170023154.review: Honestly, The Witcher 3 WildHunt is one of those games that I want to play many times. Everything was great. Especially the characterization of Geralt. The transformation from an emotionless witcher to someone who would sacrifice his life for his loved ones was the highlight. In addition, great graphics and beautiful gameplay were the advantages of The Witcher 3. I am grateful to the creators and developers of this game for giving me a good time <3

170965233.review:
I would select a neutral recommendation, but between "yes" and "no," I'll choose "no." A lot of people recommended this game—GOTY and all that stuff. I played Witcher and Witcher 2 about 6 years ago. Witcher was decent (obviously old), and Witcher 2 was good.

I finished all the quests (that I found) and the main story on "Death March" difficulty in 126 hours. I lost all desire to play the DLCs.

Here are the things I liked about this game:

 - Beautiful world with gorgeous landscapes.
 - Amazing folk-style music.
 - Rich lore (though I didn't dive deep) and a few interesting quests.
 - Broad set of characters with good voice acting.

Things I didn't like:

 - The combat system is boring and repetitive.
 - Movement is very weird and unresponsive, including horse riding.
 - I encountered multiple bugs during my playthrough, including audio/music glitches, various texture clipping/stucking, and weird ragdoll effects. Fortunately, nothing was game-breaking.
 - Gwent is an absolute filler to extend game time. Horse racing and fistfights are the same filler.
 - The difficulty is very weird. I would die from 2-3 hits until around level 10. After that point, the game became like a walk in the park (combined with the boring combat). For example, at level 20, I encountered a level 30 boss that dealt 1/5 HP damage per hit. Right after I killed this boss, I met a pack of wolves that two-shotted me.
 - The crafting system is absolutely useless. You just craft witcher gear once and upgrade it a few times during the playthrough. That's all.

I tried to be as concise as possible. I treated this game harshly because everybody praises it as something you MUST play. This game is blatantly overrated. I'm not saying the game is bad—it is still good—but I just don't like the exaggeration about how good it is, being "one of the best" and that "everyone should play it".

I really enjoyed the first 40-50 hours of the playthrough, but then it quickly went downhill after a certain point. I believe the combat and certain quest repetitiveness were the main contributors to this. The game is artificially overextended; for comparison, Witcher 2 took me ~30 hours, and I remember it as a good solid game.

6.5/10

171254502.review:
I have to admit its with a heavy heart that I give a negative review for anything.  I appreciate the work that goes into making and maintaining games especially one as beloved as this one.  The Witcher 3 didn't really engage me:  the story itself is fine, the world is large and interesting and takes place over several biospheres so its always got visual variety.  However the gameplay itself is just lacking: the combat mechanics are overly basic: the only meaningful variation to mashing your left click to attack is to use a spell of which there are only four and usually at least two of them are useless against specific types of enemy.  Ive no idea what the benefit of crafting grenades is: they never seemed to have any major effect when I tried using them; likewise the crossbow is severely under-developed: it just locks on to the nearest enemy and you can't get extra damage from headshots or critical hits etc (at least not as far as I can tell).  The environment is pretty hard to traverse in places; especially in snow-covered areas you can walk on an area that sends you slipping down to the bottom of the mountain you've just spent several minutes carefully climbing.  Likewise the horse can trip over the smallest rock yet climb a rocky hill no problem.  To be fair to the writers there is a lot of content in here but the extended dialogue choices which in a lot of cases don't change the path of the game slow the pace down a lot.  There are a lot of story lines which have needlessly complicated additional tasks added to beef them out (e.g. the interminably dull Find Dandelion strand) which would have been better if some of the more interesting side quests had been woven into the main plot to reduce the grind of the fetch and carry type main story quests.  The crafting system is by far the most complicated I've seen in a game: get a raw material, combine it with another one, craft it into something, add another thing, craft that into something else, add that to what you had before plus your existing weapon and then find a higher skill blacksmith to turn that into a nice new weapon, then add runes to decorate.  Its so dull and you need to be Rain Man to remember what components you are trying to find.
I don't want to appear wholly negative about this : I did complete the main story but it felt like a drag to the finish. If you like this kind of long-form game (and usually I do) and really want to immerse yourself in the side quests and the monster slaying then go for it but unfortunately I won't be returning.  Pam pa ram pam pa ram long live Radovid etc,

170154176.review: Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a groundbreaking RPG that excels in every aspect. Its visually stunning world, filled with intricate details and dynamic weather, sets a new standard. Combat is tactical and rewarding, with a variety of quests offering meaningful choices and consequences. The soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful, enhancing the immersive atmosphere. With expansive DLCs adding even more depth, Witcher 3 is a must-play for anyone seeking an unforgettable gaming experience.

169989356.review:
The Witcher 3 is one of those mammoth RPGs where a simple review cannot fully do it justice. There’s just so much to see and experience, with a story that will be very different from player to player, you have to experience it for yourself. Even then, to fully absorb everything the game has to offer, you’ll need to go through multiple play-throughs, making this a game that really could last months, or even years.

Mechanically, it doesn’t quite keep up with its ambitions, and the combat sluggishness, as well as an occasionally choppy frame rate and poorly designed menu do hamper it, but if you look past these problems, you’ll find one of the best RPGs, and a definite must-have title.

167641055.review:
It's 2024, and The Witcher 3 remains the best game I've ever played. I wish I could go back and experience it for the first time.

Writing this after just finishing Ghost of Tsushima Director's Cut - the game is great: well-written story, enjoyable gameplay, and visually stunning, but it made me realize that in comparison, The Witcher 3 is still on another level—a masterpiece. I've played numerous RPGs, but few come close to The Witcher 3 in terms of the overall experience, including immersion, world-building, role-playing, player choices, blend of fantasy and realism, soundtrack, and replayability. The Next-Gen update has also made the game look absolutely stunning and not at all dated. The world, especially Toussaint, is incredibly beautiful.

The combat may be the weakest part of the game and can feel slightly dated, but it's definitely playable and not as bad as some people say. My favorite aspect is preparing for combat—knowing which potions or signs to use against specific types of enemies and situations.

One aspect that sets The Witcher 3 apart from other games is the developers' attention to detail, which makes the world extremely immersive and story-rich. The variety in the side quests is remarkable in terms of storytelling, often blending elements encountered elsewhere. Many of these quests are even more entertaining than the main storyline. This attention extends to random world encounters; in most other games, it's simply about killing bandits or rescuing someone, but in The Witcher 3, you can become invested in random characters you meet on the road, sympathize with their stories, investigate, and make tough decisions that leave you pondering whether you made the right choice.

I also appreciate that throughout the game—whether in main quests, side quests, or random encounters—you have the freedom to make choices, although sometimes the wording can be misleading in certain quests. Almost every choice has impactful, sometimes far-reaching, and unexpected consequences, which enhances the world's immersion, realism, and complexity. You can play as you like, shaping Geralt as you imagine or want him to be. This freedom is something I enjoy more than RPGs where players have limited decision-making and must follow a predetermined path.

If I were to rate some of the RPGs I've enjoyed (minimum 80 hours):

The Witcher 3: 10/10
Elden Ring: 10/10
Skyrim: 9.5/10
Kingdom Come: Deliverance: 9/10
Cyberpunk: 8.5/10
Ghost of Tsushima: 8/10
Hogwarts Legacy: 8/10
Assassin's Creed Origins: 7.5/10
Assassin's Creed Odyssey: 7/10

167297215.review:
[h1] [b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - A Journey from Frustration to Fascination[/b] [/h1]

[b]Having never played the previous installments of The Witcher series[/b], I found myself diving into The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt with a mix of excitement and trepidation. From the outset, the game felt like a [b]deprecation. The clunky combat mechanics and awkward movement system were immediate turn-offs.[/b] The game's complexity was overwhelming, inundating me with a barrage of new characters and rapidly evolving plot threads before I had even grasped the controls or memorized the key bindings. [b]Each attempt to immerse myself ended in boredom and frustration, as I felt humiliated by my inability to fight, navigate, or make crucial decisions effectively.[/b]

[b]However, as I reached the 50-hour mark, a revelation dawned on me.[/b] The game is designed to be challenging and intricate, and therein lies its allure. The initial struggle became a driving force, compelling me to persevere and master the game's systems. [b]The wooden simplicity of the controls and mechanics faded into the background as I grew accustomed to them, allowing me to focus on exploring the rich, immersive world.[/b]

Delving deeper into the game, [b]I began to truly embody the role of Geralt of Rivia I felt his rage at the world, his complex relationship with Yennefer, and the weight of his quest to find Ciri.[/b] The narrative became a living, breathing experience, with each cutscene evoking genuine emotions—laughter at the witty banter and sorrow at the loss of loved ones. [b]The way Geralt's actions impacted the game world was particularly satisfying, as favors granted to various characters came full circle in the end.[/b]

The soundtrack deserves special mention for its ability to heighten every moment, from the smallest skirmish to the most pivotal plot twist. The characters' loyalty and interconnectedness added depth to the story, making my choices feel significant. Despite the initial shortcomings, these aspects overshadowed the early frustrations.

[b]After spending over 100 hours in the game, completing the main storyline and most side quests[/b], I can confidently say that [b]The Witcher 3's slow-paced development is a double-edged sword[/b]. It may deter new players with its gradual build-up, but it ultimately leads to a crescendo of non-stop action and engagement towards the end, making it hard to step away from the screen—a feeling I never experienced earlier in the game.

In conclusion, [b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a testament to the rewards of perseverance. Its initial hurdles are daunting, but they give way to a profoundly rich and engaging experience that is well worth the effort.[/b] For those willing to push through the early struggles, the game offers an unparalleled journey filled with emotion, depth, and satisfaction.

Hello
I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died.

169071588.review:
[h3]A Masterpiece of Storytelling and Adventure: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/h3]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is not just a game; it's an extraordinary journey that transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming, weaving a tale that is both deeply personal and epically grand. From the moment you step into the boots of Geralt of Rivia, you are enveloped in a world that is as breathtakingly beautiful as it is richly detailed.

[b]Narrative Excellence[/b]
The story of The Witcher 3 is a tour de force of storytelling. It masterfully blends intricate plotlines with deep character development, making you care deeply about the fate of each character you encounter. Geralt’s quest to find his adopted daughter, Ciri, against the backdrop of a world ravaged by war and political intrigue, is compelling and emotionally resonant. Every decision you make has weight and consequence, ensuring that your journey is uniquely yours.

[b]Stunning Visuals[/b]
Visually, The Witcher 3 is a work of art. The world of the Continent is brought to life with stunning detail and vibrant colors. From the dense, mysterious forests of Velen to the bustling streets of Novigrad, every location is meticulously crafted and filled with life. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle further enhance the immersion, making the world feel alive and ever-changing.

[b]Immersive Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay mechanics are equally impressive. Combat is fluid and satisfying, combining strategic planning with fast-paced action. Geralt's Witcher abilities, combined with a wide array of weapons and magic, allow for diverse combat styles that keep the gameplay fresh and exciting. The variety of quests, from the main story to side missions and monster contracts, are all crafted with care and provide a deep and rewarding experience.

[b]A Living, Breathing World[/b]
One of the game’s greatest achievements is its open world. The Witcher 3’s world is teeming with life and detail, filled with unique characters, each with their own stories and secrets. The attention to detail is staggering, making exploration a joy. Whether you are uncovering hidden treasures, solving intricate puzzles, or simply taking in the stunning landscapes, there is always something new to discover.

[b]Unforgettable Characters[/b]
The characters in The Witcher 3 are unforgettable. Geralt himself is a complex and nuanced protagonist, and the supporting cast is equally memorable. Yennefer, Triss, Ciri, and a host of other characters are all well-developed, each with their own unique personalities and arcs. The voice acting and writing are top-notch, bringing these characters to life in a way that few games achieve.

[b]Heartfelt Music[/b]
The musical score is another highlight, perfectly complementing the game’s tone and atmosphere. The hauntingly beautiful melodies stay with you long after you’ve put down the controller, enhancing the emotional impact of the story.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
In conclusion, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece that sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. Its combination of a deeply engaging story, stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and rich character development makes it an unforgettable experience. Whether you’re a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, this game is a must-play that will leave a lasting impression. CD Projekt Red has crafted a game that is not just to be played, but to be experienced, and it stands as one of the greatest achievements in gaming history.

166254437.review:
[h3][u]The Big If[/u][/h3]
Insert '[i]what can I say that hasn't already been[/i]' cliche.  In 250+ hours, all achievements conquered, all maps cleansed of their quests and points of interest, and all dlc content thoroughly explored, I can confidently say I've experienced nearly everything this game has to offer.

This was the one: CDPR's golden child.  I know i'm rather late to the party, but I finally made time to try the game I had heard such an overwhelming amount about over the last decade.  Thankfully, I was not jumping in blind as I have completed both the Witcher 1 and 2 prior to tackling this beast, and would say I enjoyed those a moderate amount.  But this--the Witcher 3--this is the one that has gained a staggeringly strong reputation over the years for being such a strong entry in the fantasy RPG genre.  Needless to say, I went in with rather high expectations.

I'll keep it short and say that those expectations were absolutely met.  The absurd level of detail and effort put into creating a living, breathing world that ensures the player will [i]not[/i] feel like the center of the universe is incredibly respectable, leaving said player with an immensely satisfying and immersive experience.  One that I could not recommend more. . . . . . . .

[h2]IF[/h2]

a primarily story driven game is what resonates with the player.  

To go on a bit of a tangent, every time there's a [i]what's a popular game that you just couldn't get into?![/i] thread on popular gaming sites or reddit, there's always 2 very common answers: Zelda, Breath of the Wild (a discussion for another day..) and the Witcher 3.  That said, despite thoroughly enjoying my time, I have [i]absolutely[/i] come to understand why so many feel they just can't get into this game.

The Witcher 3's biggest strength is that the devs knew exactly what they wanted this game to be.  The engaging story and its themes, the lively cast of characters, the beautifully detailed and immersive world?  All great stuff!  The Witcher 3 as a general experience is undeniably fantastic...

The Witcher 3 as a [i]game[/i]?... Yeeeeah there's just nothing of interest here.   The problem with the devs focusing so hard on creating a believable world is that they doubled down on finely tuning this aspect of the game, leaving the rest of the experience to suffer as a result.  The player can go [i]hours[/i] without interacting with any of the game's core mechanics if they happen to engage in a chain of story-centered quests, which doesn't necessarily have to be viewed as a bad thing, but when they do finally happen upon gameplay, it can feel under cooked.

The open world contains many memorable and varied side quests, admittedly, but contains just as many points of interest that are considered busy work in other games of a similar format.  Combat is often cited as a particularly weak part of the gameplay as it boils down to a very a simplistic dodge-and-counter loop, a complaint I can't disagree with.  There are dozens of armor/weapon sets that all differ [i]only[/i] in numerical stats until the dlc, which by then is too little too late.  Signs, this game's version of magic, are rather one-dimensional and therefore pretty limited in spicing up combat.  There are [i]hundreds[/i] of lootable items, and while not all of them add to the limit, the devs decided on keeping the weight system that plagues so many rpg's.  This isn't a survival game, so no idea why this system exists here.  The list goes on, but I feel the point across.

I can wholeheartedly recommend this title [i]if[/i] and only if the player is aware of what they're getting into.  The Witcher 3 is an experience first and game second.  The devs knew this and if you don't mind that fact, you will be treated to one of the most memorable experiences in gaming.

166851786.review:
[h1]Gwent Playing With a Side of Monster S-Mash[/h1]

[h2]A Visual Feast That’s Better Than Your Last Vacation Photos[/h2]

From the moment you boot up The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, it’s clear you’re in for a visual treat. The character models aren’t just well-crafted; they’re so expressive you might start questioning if they’re more emotionally available than your ex. And the landscapes? Oh boy, forget your last vacation photos because this game’s scenery makes them look like they were taken with a potato. You’ll find yourself stopping to admire the view so often that Geralt might as well get a side gig as a travel blogger.

[h2]Engaging Systems and Storyline That Make Netflix Binge-Worthy[/h2]

This game isn’t just a pretty face; it’s got brains too. The systems, from alchemy to combat, are designed to keep you on your toes. The storyline balances the grand scale of world politics with personal conflicts so well, you might start thinking about running for office just to have something this interesting in your life. You’ll be torn between chasing after your adopted daughter, Ciri, and diving into political intrigues so juicy they make House of Cards look like a high school student council meeting.

[h2]Combat: Like Dancing with Swords (But Less Graceful)[/h2]

Combat in The Witcher 3 is a dance, a deadly, monster-slaying dance. Geralt’s swordplay is swift and fluid, and with signs and potions in the mix, you’ll feel like a magical martial artist. However, gauging range in combat can be a bit like trying to swat a fly with a broomstick – sometimes you hit the mark, and sometimes you’re just flailing around like you’re at a rave. But when you do connect, oh, the satisfaction is real.

[h2]Weather: Beautiful but Barely There[/h2]

The dynamic weather in The Witcher 3 adds an atmospheric touch that’s as gorgeous as it is irrelevant. Sure, it’s fun to watch a storm roll in, but it could’ve done so much more. Imagine tracking a monster through a blizzard, where the wind isn’t just blowing your hair but your chances of survival. Alas, the weather is more like background noise – pretty but not really making much of a difference. It’s like having a sports car and only using it to drive to the grocery store. I hope it's getting obvious I'm grasping at straws here, trying to find drawbacks.

[h2]An End That Leaves You Wanting More (And Sobbing Uncontrollably)[/h2]

All jokes aside, the biggest downside of The Witcher 3? It ends. After countless hours of engrossing gameplay, rich storytelling, and memorable adventures, you’ll be left staring at the credits, wondering what to do with your life. The realization that your epic journey has a conclusion might have you bargaining with the gaming gods for just one more quest. But like all good things, it’s the journey that matters, even if you’re left with a void that only another replay can fill.

[h2]Verdict[/h2]

[b]Graphics: 10/10[/b]
So stunning, they might make you reconsider reality. Your eyes will thank you.

[b]Sound: 9.5/10[/b]
From epic soundtracks to immersive soundscapes, your ears are in for a treat. Just don’t start singing LELELELELE along in public.

[b]Gameplay: 9/10[/b]
Engaging and fluid, with just a touch of awkward flailing. Like a first date that goes surprisingly well.

[b]Story: 10/10[/b]
An engrossing narrative that’s better than most TV shows. Get ready to binge.

[b][u]Overall: 9.6/10[/u][/b]

[h2]Closing Thoughts: A Journey Worth Every Step (And Every Monster Guts)[/h2]

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt isn’t just a game; it’s an experience that will have you hooked from the first monster hunt to the final farewell. With its stunning visuals, deep story, and fluid combat, it sets a new standard for RPGs. Whether you’re a veteran witcher or a newcomer, this is one journey you’ll cherish. Prepare to lose yourself in a world where every choice matters and every monster has a backstory more interesting than your co-worker’s vacation slides. Just remember, the path of a witcher is tough, but oh so worth it. Get ready to dive in – just don’t forget to come up for air. Or snacks. Snacks are important.

165524634.review: This game is more than 9 years old but still people remember it with warm feelings and memories. It's a pity that I only now took the chance to play this masterpiece. Each additional quest is a separate unique story with its own idea. On the account of ambient and music in Wither 3 can only compare with RDR2 or other games that will remain in the history of video gaming only with good memories and feelings. The story itself reveals fully the characteristics of the characters and who they are. All of them are different and each has its own flavor. The graphics are still top notch even in 2024 and it's definitely 10/10. All that is terrible about this game is that it ends. I look forward to the sequel to this legendary trilogy from CD Project Red.

I’ll throw in a recipe for Chicken cutlets with mushrooms

Products
Chicken - 700 g
White bread - 50 g
Milk - 100 ml
Vegetable oil - 50 ml
Small champignons - 15 pcs.
Chicken egg - 1 pc.
Onions - 1 pc.
Garlic - 3 teeth.
Salt - to taste
Pepper - to taste


Rinse the meat, remove from the bone and cut into pieces.

Pass the prepared poultry meat through a meat grinder along with the internal fat.

Combine the minced meat with bread pre-soaked in milk. If there is no milk in the house, replace it with just water.
Add salt, ground pepper, mix thoroughly, mince again, adding peeled onion and garlic.

Pour the beaten egg into the minced meat and beat the mixture well.

Form cutlets from the prepared cutlet mass with wet hands, hiding a small whole champignon inside each one.

Fry chicken cutlets with mushrooms on both sides until golden brown.

Place the fried cutlets in a refractory dish and finish cooking in an oven preheated to 200 degrees for about 15 minutes.

Bon appetit!

168849249.review:
One day, I might write a fuller recommendation, but for now, let me say this: if you're seeking an incredible journey through a world brimming with atmosphere, captivating characters, and intricate storylines, do yourself a favor and give The Witcher 3 a real and honest try.

The game carries a reputation that precedes it, which initially affected my enjoyment. It’s not perfect—combat could be improved, there are bugs and frustrating moments, and the pacing might seem off at times—but the narratives it weaves and the sheer spectacle it offers more than compensate for these flaws. If you take the time to slow down, read the descriptions of items and books you collect, engage with its side content, and truly immerse yourself in its richly crafted world, you'll discover a gaming experience that is both unique and profoundly rewarding. This game is truly impressive.

Also, don’t miss out on playing both DLCs: Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine. These expansions are among the best I’ve ever played, providing even deeper storytelling and exploration—especially Blood and Wine. Each adds huge amounts of content that are not just features but continuations of the game's story. The DLCs serve to take what was great about the base game and distill its greatest parts into two more adventures for the player.

169716982.review: love the game ever since its release.. sadly witcher4 will be garbage thanks to cry baby inc..

169274594.review:
y'all have heard enough praises for the game. everyone is talking how great it is, and rightfully so. this game is an absolute banger, truly a masterpiece. it is a top 5 experience in my life, it can never be repeated, almost unmatchable. but enough with the praises. how would my review differ from others if i were to just praise it ?, i wanna address the big three issues people have with this game, so may someone play this masterpiece without those worries. 


This Game is Overrated
- there's no world in which witcher 3 is overrated, it's not at all. this game gets the praise it deserves. cdpr did an amazing job, a work of passion, made with love (which you can sense at every moment) they are faithul to the books. they never inrtoduce a new character without a purpose, all of the new characters in their games are written amazingly well, fitting in the universe which andrzej sapkowski have made. it's clear how much effort have been put into this game. they all deserve their praise.


- Gameplay is Bad
what do y'all want more of the gameplay ?. the gamplay isn't all about combat. yet still, the combat is fairly well. yes it's very basic attacking and dodging stuff but does it need to be super deep?, the gameplay isn't the reason you wanna play this game. yet it offer a deep character building system with tons of options and combinations to make. sure if you wanna stick to the basics (attack, dodge, repeat) you'll get bored, if you're ignoring almost all of the options the game gives you, you know that you'll get bored yourself. Even if you still wanna stick to the basics, the game have a lot to offer in order to make you stick. as i said, gameplay is not the point of witcher 3, the point is the top notch writing, excellent characters, beautiful landscapes, deep sidequests, etc. overall when i think how great witcher 3 is, gameplay is not one of the first things i'll think of, actually it's probably the last.


- It Gets Repetitive
i get this one, i got bored the first time i played, took a year break and then finished it. but i got bored after 70 hours of gameplay. can a story get boring ?, the answer is no if you ask me, the story is something consistent, it keeps you going, specially one such as witcher 3's story. can doing all the side contents get boring ?,  yes. you see i did a ton of side stuff, which made me lose interest in the story. so i got caught up playing elden ring, and it made me drop witcher 3. have i sticked to the main quests and not the side ones, would i still drop it ?. no, absolutely not. when you get bored, you're 99% sticking to the side stuff, do some main quests to get you pumped up again. side quests can get repetitive at times, which leads to boredom. 

well that's about it i guess. im not a criticizer but these issues people make with the game really bothered me, because they're other holding people from playing it. play this banger of a game, you won't regret it.

168779905.review:
[b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt[/b] is like "Game of Thrones" in an open world, where you play as Geralt of Rivia, a rugged witcher with two swords and a pocketful of sarcasm. Imagine this: magical lands, dangerous monsters, intrigues, and Geralt racing on his trusty Roach. Ready for adventures and monster hunting? Let's go!

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
[list]
    [*][b]Huge Open World[/b]: Explore dense forests, snowy mountains, and grim swamps. Something is always happening, and every corner is filled with details and stories.
    [*][b]Deep Storyline[/b]: The main story and numerous side quests are as high-quality as the main plot. There are political intrigues, personal dramas, and the search for the lost daughter, Ciri.
    [*][b]Combat System[/b]: Swords, magic, and alchemy. Fights with monsters and humans never get boring thanks to the variety of tactics and skills.
    [*][b]Characters[/b]: Charismatic and memorable characters, from Yennefer herself to the merchant selling rattlesnakes.
    [*][b]Choices and Consequences[/b]: Your decisions affect the world around you. Sometimes this leads to unpredictable and dramatic outcomes.
[/list]
[h3]Cons:[/h3]
[list]
    [*][b]Abundance of Content[/b]: The huge number of quests and activities can be overwhelming, especially for newcomers.
    [*][b]Controls[/b]: Sometimes controlling Geralt and Roach can be a bit cumbersome and cause some frustration.
    [*][b]Bugs[/b]: Despite numerous patches, the game can still suffer from various bugs.
    [*][b]Demanding on PC[/b]: The game can be demanding on hardware, and not every computer can handle it on high settings.
    [*][b]Dark Atmosphere[/b]: Constant wars, monsters, and grim stories can be depressing for some players.
[/list]
[h3]Expansion [b]Blood and Wine[/b]:[/h3]
[list]
    [*][b]New Region[/b]: Toussaint is a colorful and picturesque region reminiscent of southern France, full of new quests and adventures.
    [*][b]Castle[/b]: Geralt gets his own castle, which can be upgraded and decorated.
    [*][b]New Monsters and Quests[/b]: Many new monsters, quests, and storylines enrich the main plot.
    [*][b]Humor and Atmosphere[/b]: A lighter and more humorous atmosphere compared to the main game, adding variety.
[/list]

[b]Overall[/b], The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt with the Blood and Wine expansion is an epic adventure that takes your breath away and provides a wealth of emotions. Despite some shortcomings, the game offers a unique experience, a deep storyline, and unforgettable characters. Ready your swords and potions, and head into the Witcher's world for new exploits!

166465265.review: In Ancient Woods And Moonlit Glades, Where Shadows Dance And Light Invades, A Lone Wolf Roams, With Sword In Hand, To Cleanse The Dark And Guard The Land. With Hair Of White And Eyes Of Steel, His Presence Makes The Monsters Kneel. They Call Him Geralt, Witcher Bold, A Tale Of Legend, Fierce And Old. Through War-Torn Fields And Hunted Night, He Seeks The Beasts That Breed In Fright. With Silver Blade And Magic’s Spark, He Cuts Through Gloom, Ignites The Dark. Yet Not Just Foes He Battles Through, But Memories, Both Old And New. A love Once Lost, A Quest Of Heart, A Destiny That Set Him Apart. From Misty Swamps To Mountain Peaks, He Journeys On, The Truth He Seeks. A Hero’s Path, Both Grim And Grand. In Realms Where Myth And Men Entwine, Where Fate Is Harsh And Stars Align, He Fights For Those Who Cannot See, The Hero Known As Witcher.

165870997.review:
A generational masterpiece that you need to try at least once during your lifetime.

Story and audio wise it's simply magnificent and addictive.

As for graphics don't let 2015 release date fool you, the game is simply beautiful even if your pc can't handle the game at it's peak, and the next gen release made it even better.

The most criticised part of the game is usually the gameplay and while I can definitely understand that it's not for everyone I find it pretty enjoyable and immersive especially once you get used to it and start to understand the mechanics. Just don't expect the dynamic and fluid action from games like Elden Ring or the most recent Zelda games, as that is not the experience this game has to offer.

In terms of difficulty I believe the game is accessible to pretty much everyone, combat and some other mechanics can be bit tricky to master especially at the beginning and at higher difficulties, but the lower difficulties are there in case you just want to enjoy the story or if you aren't particularly fond of the gameplay. Also, I don't think the game is particularly grindy and you can pretty much advance the main story whenever you feel like it.

As for bugs, you might find the occasional visual bug here or there as it's common with these types of games but in all my years playing it I've never encountered anything game breaking.

The game is long and if you want to experience everything it has to offer including the DLC's you'll need a bit of free time. It's also one of those games where choices matter and sometimes you might regret the decisions you previously took. This may lead to reloading previous saves or multiple playthroughs if you're like me.

Speaking of decisions, while the game can import saves from the previous game you won't miss much if you don't do it. The game has the option to simulate the most important decisions and it's a great entry point despite being the third instalment of the series. That said, if you have the time do give the second game a try as it's also a banger and you'll get the full witcher experience. The first game, however, I cannot recommend as much and it's absolutely not for everyone. It's an older game, from a simpler time back when CDPR were still a small studio. Thankfully a remake of it is planned! Also, no decision from the first game is imported to this one, you might just not get the occasional reference.

The game also has a very active and talented modding community and CDPR even launched it's own modding tool called REDMod. If you're into that, it can be another plus.

The game is also pretty affordable and it can be found multiple times at discount throughout the year. You can easily grab the complete edition of the game for 10-12€. 

And last but not least a special shoutout to the Gwent minigame, of the best minigames ever that even led to the creation of it's own separate game (even if didn't turn out as good in the end).

TLDR - simply one of the best of all time.

165862919.review:
Waited years to be able to play the Witcher 3.  Wanted to play handheld, wanted all the bugs ironed out.  Tried to play on the switch and the graphics were a mess.  Finally got a Steamdeck and dove in face first into this masterpiece.
Do not regret single moment, and the deck played it well.  Locked it out at 45FPS, and no stutters or frame dips.  Highly recommend it.
